Award.AwardTitle: Loops Within Loops: Optimal Distribution Networks and Leaf Vein Architecture
Award.AbstractNarration:
It has been known since the time of Edison that optimally distributing fungible goods, such as electricity or water, requires hierarchical systems consisting of trunks, mains and subsidiaries. Most biological distribution networks are hierarchical in this sense, and their elements come in vastly different sizes. But also, many biological distribution networks, such as the veins of a leaf, the arterioles in the surface of the cerebral cortex, or the veins of a dragonfly wing, have a fabric-like texture. Such networks do not only contain the links with the most direct route from the source, but also many cross-bracing connections, that permit it to continue functioning even when elements are damaged or temporarily clogged, and to maximize capacity when only part of the organism is demanding the good. The cross-bracing connections form closed loops, and they themselves are hierarchical, so the networks look like little loops nested within larger loops, not unlike networks of highways, avenues, streets and alleys.

This project will develop the theory of such loopy hierarchical architectures, with a particular emphasis to understanding how the tradeoffs between the different and often conflicting requirements of minimal cost, resistance to damage, resistance to fluctuating loads, and maximum acceptable gradients result in the complex, beautiful and subtly distinct patterns observed in nature. The PI will develop mathematical ways, given a natural exemplar of such patterns, to read off from its the architecture the particular combination of costs that shaped it. These methods will be applied to a large database of leaves, to try to correlate their architectural differences with their environment and physiology. Finally, artificial versions of these networks will be generated and their performance characterized experimentally. New theory and experimental data from this project will illuminate our understanding, not only of the plant kingdom, but also of design principles for our own vascular systems.

The proposed research will contribute directly to education and outreach programs for high school students, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. These activities will be coordinated through ongoing programs at Rockefeller University. Promoting the involvement of minority undergraduate and graduate students in research environments will be a priority of this program. Results from the project will be incorporated into novel graduate courses on network theory and advanced modeling for biology students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It has been known since Edison that efficiency in the distribution of resources requires a hierarchy: in order to efficiently distribute electric power from the power plant, or water from a reservoir, or cars through a city, you need a hierarchy of distribution methods. In the case of electric distribution, Edison envisioned only three levels (main conductors on the main street of a town, subsiduary conductors on side streets and derived circuits going into the houses), but several more levels have been added in modern times (various high-voltage and medium voltage distribution networks etc) as the distribution became transcontinental. Sheer efficiency in view of a predictable demand only requires this hierarchy to be treelike, meaning that from the source there is a single path to each place where the demand occurs. 

However many biological systems show complex distribution networks that exhibit both a hierarchy as well as a large number of cross-connections that give the network a fabric-like texture. Everyone is familiar with picking up a half-rotten leaf in the woods in fall, and the feeling that the network of wooden veins that remains after the leafy flesh has decayed away is like a piece of gauze, in that it somewhat resists shearing. This rich interconnection allows the network to resist damage, such as holes in a leaf caused by insects or pathogens. 

 

This Grant studied models of, and method to characterize, such complex biological networks. The venation of leaves remains our primary model because of a number of advantages: they are readily observable, for example by fluorophor injection into the water; they are plentiful; and, finally and not least, we do not currently have a fully-developed understanding of what causes underlie the subtle differences in their structure and shape. Other vasculatures of great interest include the surface venation of the cerebral cortex, which underlies all delivery of oxygen and nutrients to our "gray matter" and the structure of filamentous fungi, which form enormous underground networks which are symbionts of wood trees, such as the "humungous fungus", the largest living organism. 

Under this Grant we developed sophisticated methods with which we can take an image of such vasculature and "deconstruct" it, to tell us how smaller loops are embedded within larger loops. This has permitted us to quantify the differences between different vasculatures, as well as the differences in structure between different species of trees. 

Finally, there is a great deal of interest in three-dimensional vasculature, such as our arterial/venous system as it irrigates most organs. This grant attacked and succeeded in producing a method for the analysis of such 3D vasculature, which we are trying to apply to such systems as the vasculature of livers.
